title: Clinical Waste Collection Service
text:
About clinical waste
Clinical waste is the collection of any items of waste that may cause infection to any person coming into contact with it. This type of waste requires a specialist collection and must be disposed of in the correct container.
Please note that clinical waste bags and sharps bins are not collected with regular household waste. They require a separate collection with its own schedule.

title: Clinical Waste Collection Service
text:
Types of clinical waste
Type of clinical waste
Container
Human tissue
Yellow and black bags
Blood, bodily fluids, infectious waste
Yellow and black bags
Swabs or dressings
Yellow bags
Syringes, needles or other sharp instruments
Yellow box
Excretions
Double bag and placed in maroon general waste bin.
Drugs or other pharmaceutical products
These are not collected please speak to your GP or local pharmacist.
Containers and bags will be delivered once the request from your medical professional has been processed.
We will not collect items in other containers. Boxes with any other colour lid should be returned to the original provider such as medical centre or hospital

title: Clinical Waste Collection Service
text:
Clinical collection days
Each individual who requires a clinical collection will be sent a collection calendar by post or email which sets out the day and frequency of the collection.
Clinical collections will take place over four days from Tuesday to Friday. You will be informed of your specific collection day. Please check your calendar for the exact dates.
Duplicate calendars can be requested,
please contact customer service.
2025 Calendars
Clinical Waste service has sent out calendars for collection dates in 2025 to all quarterly and monthly residents requiring collections. Please refer to the new calendar you have received before reporting a missed collection.
Weekly collections- no change to collection day
Six monthly or annual collections - please contact customer service to arrange a collection.

links.context: Duplicate calendars can be requested,please contact customer service.

title: Clinical Waste Collection Service
text:
On your collection day
Bags must be tied and double knotted and boxes sealed closed.
They must be left on your doorstep or in sight of the road from 7am until 3pm on the collection day.

title: Clinical Waste Collection Service
text:
Report a missed clinical collection
Before reporting a missed collection, we ask that you check your calendar to confirm the collection date.
If you still need to report a missed collection,
please contact customer service.
Once reported the missed clinical waste collection should be re-collected within 5 days, unless the collection crew are due in the area earlier or are urgently required.

links.context: If you still need to report a missed collection,please contact customer service.

title: Clinical Waste Collection Service
text:
Sign up for the Clinical Waste Collection Service
If you need to dispose of clinical waste at home, you can join our dedicated collection service. However, applications must be submitted by a medical professional on your behalf using the online form below.
Once the form is received and processed, we will send you the specific collection schedule and any additional information you might need.
Medical professionals can find the collection form here

links.text: Medical professionals can find the collection form here
links.context: Medical professionals can find the collection form here

title: Bulky waste collection
summary: If you want to dispose of large or heavy items which won’t go into your household waste bin, you can arrange for them to be collected separately.
intro: If you want to dispose of large or heavy items which won’t go into your household waste bin, you can arrange for them to be collected separately.
text:
We do not collect fixtures and fittings such as bathroom furniture, internal and external doors, and kitchens. If you are unsure if your bulky waste fits the criteria, please check the list below.
Costs
To schedule a collection, there is a fee of £28 for up to five items or £55 for six to ten items.
Collection days
We have set collection days for specific areas in Knowsley.
Monday & Thursday – Huyton & Stockbridge Village
Tuesday & Friday – Prescot, Whiston, Cronton, Knowsley Village, Halewood
Wednesday – Kirkby
Your collection date and day will be allocated as per your area at the time of your booking.
We do not offer collections on weekends or bank holidays.
Please note the above days are subject to change due to service demands.
Amending or cancelling your booking
To make changes or cancel your bulky waste collection booking, log in to your account on our online portal. You can do this anytime before 12 p.m. on the day before your collection date.
Cancellations made in time will receive a full refund.
On collection day
Our team will collect the bulky items between 7 a.m. and 4 p.m. on the agreed day. Here's what you need to do:
Disassemble larger items as much as possible.
Ensure that mattresses, sofas, and similar items are protected from the rain to prevent them from becoming too heavy to remove.
Place the items in front of your property or from the location your bins are collected if you do not have a front path or driveway before 7 a.m on the collection day.
Ensure clear access to your property; please don't obstruct your driveway.
Items we cannot collect
While booking, you'll specify which items to remove. However, our collection team won't be able to retrieve items if:
They consider it unsafe to enter the property.
The items weren't left on the ground floor, and there's no suitable lift available.
If your bulky items can't be collected, you'll receive a notice explaining why they weren't retrieved and who to contact.
Book a bulky waste collection

links.context: Book a bulky waste collection

title: What we can collect
summary: We offer collection services for a large range of bulky items, including furniture, kitchen appliances, and items from your garden or yard.
intro: We offer collection services for a large range of bulky items, including furniture, kitchen appliances, and items from your garden or yard.
text:
We offer collection services for a wide variety of household items, such as:
Large household appliances (e.g., fridges, cookers, microwaves, washing machines, and dishwashers)
Entertainment equipment (e.g., televisions, hi-fi systems, and computers)
Comfortable furniture (including sofas and armchairs)
Dining essentials (tables and chairs)
Outdoor gear (bicycles and garden furniture)
Bedroom essentials (beds and mattresses)
Carpets and rugs only (no laminates)
During the booking process, you'll specify the items to be collected. However, please note that our collection team may not be able to retrieve items from your property if:
They deem it unsafe to enter your property.
The items are not left on the ground floor, and there's no suitable lift available for use.
If your bulky items cannot be collected for these reasons, you'll receive a notice at your doorstep explaining why they were not retrieved and providing contact information for further assistance.
Book a bulk waste collection

links.context: Book a bulk waste collection

title: Recycling
summary: Find out more about recycling at home and about recycling centres (tips) in Knowsley, acceptable trailer and van sizes, and how to book a van appointment.
intro: Find out more about recycling at home and about recycling centres (tips) in Knowsley, acceptable trailer and van sizes, and how to book a van appointment.
text:
Recycling at home
You can find information about how to recycle at home by clicking
here
.
Recycling centres
The two Household Waste Recycling Centres in Knowsley are provided by Merseyside Recycling & Waste Authority and accept a range of general household and bulky waste materials for recycling.
Vans and trailers
An appointment system is in place at all Household Waste Recycling Centres if you are using a commercial-type vehicle such as a van, or a trailer sized between 2 and 3 metres (external box dimensions).
Residents using a van of any size or a large trailer are allowed a maximum of 12 visits per year to recycle and dispose of household waste, including green and garden waste.
You do not need to book an appointment if using a standard car unless you are towing a trailer sized between 2 and 3 metres.
Visit the
MRWA website
to book an appointment online, or alternatively call 0151 255 1444.
Asbestos disposal
Householders can dispose of cement bonded asbestos products at the the Huyton recycling centre, located on Wilson Road, L36 6AD, by appointment only.
Visit the
Veolia website
to book the asbestos disposal service, or alternatively call 0203 567 4200.
How to book an appointment
Making an appointment is easy and free of charge. You can use the online booking system or contact the recycling centre by phone.

title: Report a missed bin collection
summary: Find out more about what to do if your bin is missed.
intro: Find out more about what to do if your bin is missed.
text:
If your bin is missed, you need to report it after 3pm on your collection day, within 48 hours of your collection window. Anything after 48 hours can not be reported.
We cannot collect your bin if
it is too heavy
it contains the wrong items
it is too full
the lid is open
it is not put out by 7am on your collection day
What to do if your bin is too heavy or contains the wrong items
Please remove any heavy or incorrect items from your bin to ensure that it is collected. Remember, you can also take the waste yourself to your nearest
Household Waste Recycling Centre in Knowsley
.
What you will need when reporting a missed bin collection
Provide your full address and postcode
Type of bin missed
Date of the missed collection
Report a missed bin collection

links.text: Household Waste Recycling Centre in Knowsley
links.context: Please remove any heavy or incorrect items from your bin to ensure that it is collected. Remember, you can also take the waste yourself to your nearestHousehold Waste Recycling Centre in Knowsley.
Report a missed bin collection

title: Fly tipping
summary: Information on appropriate waste disposal and how to report fly tipping incidents.
intro: Information on appropriate waste disposal and how to report fly tipping incidents.
text:
Fly tipping is the illegal dumping of waste and is considered a crime.
Fly tipping is dangerous, damages the environment and costs a huge amount of money to clean up each year.
Abandoned rubbish can lead to increased rodent activity, the perception of increased crime levels, and overall safety concerns. It also encourages others to dump their rubbish there.
Fly tipping in Knowsley
Not all fly tipping collections are the responsibility of Knowsley Council, please read the information below before reporting, to ensure you are reporting the issue to the correct organisation.
You can also report major incidents of fly tipping to the Environment Agency on 0800 555 111.
If the fly tipping is on a Social Landlord’s property such as Livv Housing Group, Riverside Housing or ForHousing you must contact them directly to arrange for the fly tipping to be removed.
How to report fly tipping to Knowsley Council
If you would like to report fly tipping to Knowsley Council, please click below.
The report will be passed to the Streetscene Service who will remove fly tipped items from council owned land within five working days.
We treat fly tipping very seriously and anyone caught will be prosecuted.
Report fly tipping
Contact Social Landlords
LIVV Housing
0151 290 7000
contactcentre@livvhousinggroup.com
ForHousing
0300 123 5522
hello@forhousing.co.uk
Riverside Housing
0345 111 0000
Click here to report

links.context: Report fly tipping
contactcentre@livvhousinggroup.com
hello@forhousing.co.uk
Click here to report

title: Waste duty of care
summary: You have a duty of care to dispose of your waste responsibly, find out more about ways to comply and advice for businesses.
intro: You have a duty of care to dispose of your waste responsibly, find out more about ways to comply and advice for businesses.
text:
Everyone who produces waste has a duty of care to ensure that it is disposed of properly and transferred to someone who is authorised to receive it. This is under section 34 of the Environmental Protection Act 1990
If your waste is found illegally fly tipped, you could be held responsible and prosecuted.
Tips on how to comply with your waste duty of care
Check that the company you are using to remove your waste is registered with the Environment Agency.
You can do this by calling 03708 506506 or visiting their website.
Ask the company to see their registration certificate.
This should start with CBDU, followed by a set of numbers. Take a photo of the certificate if possible.
Do not pay cash.
Ask for an invoice or receipt that includes the business details and pay by a secure payment method or cheque. This will make it easier to trace the payment if your waste is fly tipped.
Record the details of the person collecting your waste and the vehicles used.
This includes the make, model, colour, and registration mark.
Be wary of companies that offer their services at a very low price.
If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. If you’re hiring a skip, the average cost should be around £150
Waste carrier registration
A waste carrier registration is normally needed for the following categories
All building and associated trades
Landscape gardeners, tree fellers and surgeons
House clearers
Retail establishments and
Scrap metal dealers
Using private contractors
If you hire a private contractor to collect household, garden, or construction waste, ensure they're registered with the Environment Agency and hold a waste carrier's licence. Failure to do so could result in an unlimited fine.
Businesses
Businesses have additional responsibilities under the waste duty of care. In addition to the tips above, you must also
Provide an accurate description of the waste when it is transferred to another person.
Keep all records for a minimum of two years.
Failure to comply with the waste duty of care requirements is a criminal offence and could lead to prosecution.
Knowsley Household Recycling and Waste Centres
Alternatively, residents can dispose of their waste at Knowsley’s two Household Recycling and Waste Centres run by the Merseyside Recycling and Waste Authority.
Find out more information
here.

links.context: Find out more informationhere.

title: Dog control orders
summary: Dog control orders in Knowsley require owners to carry bags, keep dogs on leads, and stay out of certain areas. Find out more here.
intro: Dog control orders in Knowsley require owners to carry bags, keep dogs on leads, and stay out of certain areas. Find out more here.
text:
Knowsley Council has a Public Spaces Protection Order (PSPO) to promote responsible dog ownership in the borough. Anyone who fails to comply with the PSPO could face a fine of up to £100. The Order takes effect on 28 January 2025 and has a duration of 3 years.
The PSPO requires dog owners to
Remove dog fouling
Requiring a person in control of a dog (or dogs) to put their dog(s) on a lead when directed by an authorised officer
Keep dogs on a lead within all in council-owned cemeteries, allotments and golf courses
Requiring those in control of a dog to have on their person a bag or other means to collect dog waste from the ground
Keep dogs on a lead in designated woodland areas
Keep dogs on a lead within all designated carriageways (A and B classified roads) and footways
Restricting the number of dogs that can be walked by one person to a maximum of six dogs on or off the lead; and
Exclude dogs from all children’s play areas, enclosed multi use games areas, and areas used for some other sporting or leisure purpose.
The PSPO will be in place for three years from the commencement date.
Downloads
Read the PSPO in full here and find areas where particular orders cover.

title: Fixed penalties for environmental crimes
summary: A Fixed Penalty Notice (FPN) is a fine issued by an authorised officer for a minor offence, such as littering or dog fouling. It is an alternative to prosecution in court. Find out more about how to pay and appeal here.
intro: A Fixed Penalty Notice (FPN) is a fine issued by an authorised officer for a minor offence, such as littering or dog fouling. It is an alternative to prosecution in court. Find out more about how to pay and appeal here.
text:
Knowsley Council issue Fixed Penalty Notices (FPNs) for a variety of environmental crimes, including:
Littering
Smoking in a smoke-free area
Not complying with the Public Space Protection Order (PSPO) in relation to
dog control
Fly tipping
Failure to comply with the duty of care for household waste (residents) and business waste
Not having the correct documentation in relation to waste storage, transfer, or disposal
Breaches of Community Protection Notices
How to pay your Fixed Penalty Notice
All information on how you can pay is on the reverse of your FPN.
Online
Knowsley Metropolitan Council Pay Portal
Telephone
0151 443 2300
Appealing a Fixed Penalty Notice
You can appeal an FPN in the Magistrates Court. However, you have only 21 days from the date the notice was issued to do so.
To appeal an FPN, you must fill out a Notice of Appeal form and send it to the Magistrates Court. Details of appeals are provided when an FPN is issued.
If you feel that an FPN has been served incorrectly
You can make representations by sending them by email
to
environmentalhealth@knowsley.gov.uk
or by contacting the officer who issued the FPN; you will find their details in the accompanying letter if you received one with your FPN.

links.context: Not complying with the Public Space Protection Order (PSPO) in relation todog control
Knowsley Metropolitan Council Pay Portal

You can make representations by sending them by emailtoenvironmentalhealth@knowsley.gov.ukor by contacting the officer who issued the FPN; you will find their details in the accompanying letter if you received one with your FPN.

title: What to put in your bin
source: What to put in your bin
summary: If you put the wrong things in your bins we may not collect it. Find out what goes in which coloured bin and how to recycle at home here.
intro: If you put the wrong things in your bins we may not collect it. Find out what goes in which coloured bin and how to recycle at home here.
text:
What to put in each bin
What goes in the grey bin
Please rinse plastic bottles, cans and tins and glass jars before putting them in your grey bin, and flatten cardboard.
What goes in the blue bin
Do not put card, soil or food waste in your blue bin.
What goes in the maroon bin
Extra waste
Extra waste left next to your maroon or blue bins will not be collected. If you do have extra waste, please visit your nearest Household Waste Recycling Centre - details can be found
here
.
Recycling bin (grey)
General waste (maroon)
Garden waste (blue)
Food/cereal boxes
Cardboard
Phone books
Food tins and drink cans (place lids inside cans)
Glass bottles and jars (remove caps and lids)
Plastic – bottle shaped plastics only (remove tops, caps and lids)
Envelopes
Paper, newspapers and magazines
Junk mail
Polystyrene
Plastic tubs
Juice cartons (Tetra Pak)
Plant pots
Foil trays / tin foil
Plastic wrappers
Food waste - includes fruit fallen from trees
General waste and items that cannot be recycled.
Building materials or rubble are not accepted
Grass cuttings
Shredded paper
Flowers
Prunings
Hedge and tree clippings
Twigs and branches
Leaves
Plants and weeds
Untreated bark and wood chippings
Pet bedding - wood chippings, sawdust, straw and hay (clean or soiled)
Please note that all food waste, including any fruit that has fallen from the trees, should be placed in your maroon bin for collection.
Coming in Spring 2026 - Food Waste Collections
We're pleased to announce the launch of our new weekly household food waste collection service from Spring 2026!
This initiative is a significant step towards lowering our carbon footprint and creating valuable biogas for energy use. By separating your food waste, you'll be playing a vital role in building a more sustainable future for our community. This new service makes it easier than ever to dispose of food scraps responsibly, ensuring they're turned into something beneficial rather than ending up in general waste.
We understand you may have questions about what can and can't be included, how to store your food waste, and the collection schedule. To help you get started, we've compiled a comprehensive
Frequently Asked Questions
. You'll find all the information you need there for the time being, including the types of food waste accepted.
Please take a moment to review the FAQ's to ensure a smooth transition to this new service. More information about specific collection dates and food waste containers will be announced in the near future, so please keep your eyes open for updates.
We appreciate your cooperation and commitment to making our region greener!

links.context: Extra waste left next to your maroon or blue bins will not be collected. If you do have extra waste, please visit your nearest Household Waste Recycling Centre - details can be foundhere.

We understand you may have questions about what can and can't be included, how to store your food waste, and the collection schedule. To help you get started, we've compiled a comprehensiveFrequently Asked Questions. You'll find all the information you need there for the time being, including the types of food waste accepted.

title: Replacement wheelie bins and bin repairs
source: Replacement wheelie bins and bin repairs
summary: Find out how to request a new bin, repair a bin, and manage a bin order such as cancelling or returns.
intro: Find out how to request a new bin, repair a bin, and manage a bin order such as cancelling or returns.
text:
You can request a new bin or bin repair if you have moved into a new or existing property with no bin or if your bin has been damaged, lost or stolen.
There is currently no charge for a recycling (grey) or garden (blue bin)
A 240 litre General Waste (maroon) bin charge is £36
Deliveries will be completed as soon as possible.
Bin orders
Find out more about our bin charges
here.
Extra bins for large families
If your household consists of six or more people, you can apply for a second maroon bin.
Residents are encouraged to request an additional recycling bin. Please note there is a charge for additional maroon bins.
To request an additional bin, you will need to
contact us
.
alert:
Delays with bin deliveries and repairs
There is currently a delay with bin deliveries and repairs of approximately 6 weeks.   We aim to complete these as soon as possible and apologise for any inconvenience.
Any urgent orders can be collected from our depot at Monday - Friday between 9.30am -3.30pm from KMBC Depot, Stretton Way, Huyton, L36 6JF. Proof of payment will be required for Maroon bins if applicable.
Hide

links.context: Bin orders
Find out more about our bin chargeshere.
To request an additional bin, you will need tocontact us.

title: More information about our bin charges
source: More information about our bin charges
summary: Find out more about our bin charges here.
intro: Find out more about our bin charges here.
text:
The council requires a replacement fee for lost, stolen, or missing maroon bins. The fee is £36 for a 240 litre wheeled bin. This fee helps offset the administrative and delivery costs associated with providing a replacement bin.
To prevent bin theft, take the bin in as soon as possible after collection and label it with your house number/name and postcode.
Grey and blue bins are still provided free of charge to encourage recycling.
In case of bin damage, the council will make every effort to repair it rather than replace it. If a repair is not possible, a replacement bin will be provided free of charge.
If your bin has fallen into the back of the bin lorry, order a new bin online and select the reason "back of wagon." The service will contact you to confirm if they have been able to verify your bin has gone into the back of the vehicle. If this can't be verified, then a charge will apply.
There is no charge for downsizing any bin from a 360 litre to a 240 litre bin.
An extra grey recycling bin is free, but an extra maroon bin requires consultation with a customer service advisor.
Payment for a bin is by debit or credit card and must be made in full before delivery.
There is no appeal process for the replacement fee.

title: Help putting your bin out
summary: If you are elderly or have a disability and you do not have anyone else at home to help put your bin out, we may be able to help you. You can also let us know if you no longer require assistance. Find out how here.
intro: If you are elderly or have a disability and you do not have anyone else at home to help put your bin out, we may be able to help you. You can also let us know if you no longer require assistance. Find out how here.
text:
Many individuals face challenges in placing their bins out for collection due to factors such as age, disability, or physical limitations.
Recognising these difficulties, we can provide assistance programs to support residents who require help with this task.
Request or cancel assistance here
or you can call us on 0151 443 2400.

links.context: Request or cancel assistance here

title: Disposing of other items
summary: Find our more about how to dispose of bulky waste, hazardous items, or clinical waste.
intro: Find our more about how to dispose of bulky waste, hazardous items, or clinical waste.
text:
Large or bulky items
If you have large or bulky items that you need to dispose of, such as furniture, appliances, or mattresses, you can take them to a large item collection point. Find out more about
the bulky waste collection service.
Hazardous waste
Hazardous waste, such as asbestos, fuels and oils, industrial chemicals, weed killer, and creosote, can be dangerous to dispose of incorrectly. If you have hazardous waste, you should contact the Merseyside Recycling and Waste Authority on 0151 255 1444.
If you find hazardous waste on public land in Knowsley, please call the council on 0151 443 2400.
Clinical waste
Clinical waste, such as needles, syringes, and other medical supplies, should not be disposed of in your general waste bin. If you have clinical waste, you should contact your doctor's surgery or local health centre to arrange for a collection.

links.context: If you have large or bulky items that you need to dispose of, such as furniture, appliances, or mattresses, you can take them to a large item collection point. Find out more aboutthe bulky waste collection service.

title: Tips for reducing waste
summary: Here are some tips for reducing the amount of waste produced by your household.
intro: Here are some tips for reducing the amount of waste produced by your household.
text:
Use a reusable bag
Instead of using disposable plastic bags when you go shopping, get a reusable bag and bring it with you every time.
Refuse junk mail
Junk mail is a major source of waste, so take steps to reduce the amount you receive. You can sign up for the
Mail Preference Service
, which will stop most companies from sending you unsolicited mail.
Compost your garden waste
Composting is a great way to reduce your garden waste and create nutrient-rich compost that you can use to improve your soil.
Find out more here
.
Get electronic bills and statements
Many companies now offer the option to receive bills and statements electronically.
Use reusable nappies
Disposable nappies are a major source of waste, so switching to reusable nappies can make a big difference.
Find out more here.
Reduce food waste
Food waste is another major source of waste, so there are many things you can do to reduce it. Plan your meals, store food properly, and compost food scraps.
Find out more here.
Recycle Right
Recycle Right
is a program that provides information on what can and cannot be recycled in Merseyside and Halton. You can find more information on the Recycle Right website.

links.context: Junk mail is a major source of waste, so take steps to reduce the amount you receive. You can sign up for theMail Preference Service, which will stop most companies from sending you unsolicited mail.
Composting is a great way to reduce your garden waste and create nutrient-rich compost that you can use to improve your soil.Find out more here.
Disposable nappies are a major source of waste, so switching to reusable nappies can make a big difference.Find out more here.
Food waste is another major source of waste, so there are many things you can do to reduce it. Plan your meals, store food properly, and compost food scraps.Find out more here.
Recycle Rightis a program that provides information on what can and cannot be recycled in Merseyside and Halton. You can find more information on the Recycle Right website.

title: Putting your bins out
summary: Find out more about where to leave your bin, when your bin will be emptied, and what to do with excess recycling and waste.
intro: Find out more about where to leave your bin, when your bin will be emptied, and what to do with excess recycling and waste.
text:
Household waste is collected weekly, alternating between general waste one week and recycling the next. Garden waste is collected once every three weeks during the gardening season from March to November.
Place your bin out:
on the kerbside outside your property
with the lid fully closed
before 7am on your collection day
where it can be seen easily
Your bin will be emptied between 7am and 3pm.
Find out your bin days
Search by postcode to find out when your bins are emptied
Extra recycling
Extra recycling can be placed next to your grey bin if it is put in a cardboard box or clear plastic bag (not a bin bag or carrier bag).
Please make sure the cardboard box is small enough to fit into your wheeled bin, as our crews will need to place it into the bin so it can be emptied into the bin lorry.
Extra waste
Please note that extra waste left next to your maroon or blue bins will not be collected.
If you do have extra waste, please
find your nearest recycling centre
.

links.text: Search by postcode to find out when your bins are emptied
links.context: Search by postcode to find out when your bins are emptied
If you do have extra waste, pleasefind your nearest recycling centre.

title: Clinical waste
summary: Clinical waste and sharps bins require separate collection. Medical professionals must submit an online form on your behalf to join the dedicated service. Find out more here.
intro: Clinical waste and sharps bins require separate collection. Medical professionals must submit an online form on your behalf to join the dedicated service. Find out more here.
text:
Please note that clinical waste bags and sharps bins are not collected with regular household waste. They require a separate collection with its own schedule.
Clinical waste is the collection of any items of waste that may cause infection to any person coming into contact with it. This type of waste requires a specialist collection and must be disposed of in the correct container.
Type of clinical waste
Container
Human tissue
Yellow and black bags
Blood, bodily fluids, infectious waste
Yellow and black bags
Swabs or dressings
Yellow bags
Syringes, needles or other sharp instruments
Yellow box
Excretions
Double bag and placed in maroon general waste bin.
Drugs or other pharmaceutical products
These are not collected please speak to your GP or local pharmacist.
Containers and bags will be delivered once the request from your medical professional has been processed.
We will not collect items in other containers. Boxes with any other colour lid should be returned to the original provider such as medical centre or hospital.
Clinical collection days
Each individual who requires a clinical collection will be sent a collection calendar by post or email which sets out the day and frequency of the collection.
Clinical collections will take place over four days, from Tuesday to Friday. You will be informed of your specific collection day. Please check your calendar for the exact dates.
Duplicate calendars can be requested,
please contact customer service.
On your collection day
Bags must be tied and double knotted, and boxes sealed closed.
They must be left on your doorstep or in sight of the road from 7am until 3pm on the collection day.
Report a missed clinical collection
Before reporting a missed collection, we ask that you check your calendar to confirm the collection date.
If you still need to report a missed collection,
please contact customer service.
Once reported the missed clinical waste collection should be re-collected within 5 days unless they are due in the area earlier or are urgently required.
Joining the Clinical Waste Collection Service
If you need to dispose of clinical waste at home, you can join our dedicated collection service. However, applications must be submitted by a medical professional on your behalf using the online form below.
Once the form is received and processed, we will send you the specific collection schedule and any additional information you might need.
Medical professionals can find the collection form here

links.context: Duplicate calendars can be requested,please contact customer service.
If you still need to report a missed collection,please contact customer service.

links.text: Medical professionals can find the collection form here
links.context: Medical professionals can find the collection form here

title: Your household bins
summary: Find out more about bin collection schedules, reporting missed collections, requesting new bins, assisted collection services, and bin charge, alongside helpful tips on minimising household waste and maximising your recycling efforts.
intro: Find out more about bin collection schedules, reporting missed collections, requesting new bins, assisted collection services, and bin charge, alongside helpful tips on minimising household waste and maximising your recycling efforts.
text:
Putting your bins out
Find out more about where to leave your bin, when your bin will be emptied, and what to do with excess recycling and waste.
Help putting your bin out
If you are elderly or have a disability and you do not have anyone else at home to help put your bin out, we may be able to help you. You can also let us know if you no longer require assistance. Find out how here.
What to put in your bin
If you put the wrong things in your bins we may not collect it. Find out what goes in which coloured bin and how to recycle at home here.
Report a missed bin collection
Find out more about what to do if your bin is missed.
Missed collections we're aware of
Find out up to date information on missed bin collections that we are aware of.
Replacement wheelie bins and bin repairs
Find out how to request a new bin, repair a bin, and manage a bin order such as cancelling or returns.
Disposing of other items
Find our more about how to dispose of bulky waste, hazardous items, or clinical waste.
Tips for reducing waste
Here are some tips for reducing the amount of waste produced by your household.
More information about our bin charges
Find out more about our bin charges here.
